articles.headline: Companies Warn of Hits From Tax Cuts. Don’t Be Fooled.
articles.snippet: Companies are expected to report billions of dollars in short-term losses stemming from the new tax law. But they are a prelude to much larger profits.
articles.abstract: Companies are expected to report billions of dollars in short-term losses stemming from the new tax law. But they are a prelude to much larger profits.
articles.lead_paragraph: It will sound like bad news.

articles.headline: In Norway, Electric and Hybrid Cars Outsell Conventional Models
articles.snippet: The country offers generous benefits to buyers of vehicles that run on new types of fuel, making ownership more affordable.
articles.abstract: The country offers generous benefits to buyers of vehicles that run on new types of fuel, making ownership more affordable.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sales of electric and hybrid cars in Norway outpaced those running on fossil fuels last year, cementing the country’s position as a global leader in the push to restrict vehicle emissions.
articles.byline: By Amie Tsang and Henrik Pryser Libell

articles.headline: After Dow 25,000, the Party Has to End. But When?
articles.snippet: Market veterans say that stocks are overvalued and that a downturn is overdue. The question is how messy it will be, and how investors should prepare.
articles.abstract: Market veterans say that stocks are overvalued and that a downturn is overdue. The question is how messy it will be, and how investors should prepare.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the midst of a long-running bull market that is now reaching momentous proportions, most investors may well have forgotten that just two years ago, during the first five trading days of 2016, the market dropped 6 percent. It was the worst five-day start to a year ever and supposedly a harbinger of bad times.

articles.headline: Trump Closes Voter Fraud Panel That Bickered More Than It Revealed
articles.snippet: After announcing an inquiry into voter fraud shortly after his inauguration, President Trump has disbanded the group after it encountered controversy after controversy.
articles.abstract: After announcing an inquiry into voter fraud shortly after his inauguration, President Trump has disbanded the group after it encountered controversy after controversy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Presidential Advisory Commission on Election Integrity, which was disbanded this week by the White House, grew out of a presidential tweet.
articles.byline: By Michael Wines and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Rise of Bitcoin Competitor Ripple Creates Wealth to Rival Zuckerberg
articles.snippet: A co-founder of Ripple, a virtual currency, could briefly lay claim to being the world’s fifth richest person on Thursday, bypassing Mark Zuckerberg, as the Bitcoin boom widened.
articles.abstract: A co-founder of Ripple, a virtual currency, could briefly lay claim to being the world’s fifth richest person on Thursday, bypassing Mark Zuckerberg, as the Bitcoin boom widened.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The virtual currency boom has gotten so heated that it is throwing the list of the world’s richest people into disarray.

articles.headline: Obstruction Inquiry Shows Trump’s Struggle to Keep Grip on Russia Investigation
articles.snippet: The special counsel’s investigation has uncovered several episodes involving the president that raise questions about whether he obstructed justice.
articles.abstract: The special counsel’s investigation has uncovered several episodes involving the president that raise questions about whether he obstructed justice.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump gave firm instructions in March to the White House’s top lawyer: stop the attorney general, Jeff Sessions, from recusing himself in the Justice Department’s investigation into whether Mr. Trump’s associates had helped a Russian campaign to disrupt the 2016 election.

articles.headline: U.S. Job Market’s Strength Is Allowing More to Share in Pay Gains
articles.snippet: Though wages are growing sluggishly over all, some of the strongest increases are in blue-collar and service industries as employers vie for help.
articles.abstract: Though wages are growing sluggishly over all, some of the strongest increases are in blue-collar and service industries as employers vie for help.
articles.lead_paragraph: The bustling United States economy is beginning to benefit some American workers who have not gotten a taste of the recovery and have been most in need of relief.

articles.headline: An Eyelash-Freezing ‘Icy Hell’: The One Spot That Could Feel Like Minus 100
articles.snippet: Frigid air is gripping the East Coast, and furious winds are expected to make it feel as cold as 100 degrees below zero atop Mount Washington in New Hampshire.
articles.abstract: Frigid air is gripping the East Coast, and furious winds are expected to make it feel as cold as 100 degrees below zero atop Mount Washington in New Hampshire.
articles.lead_paragraph: GORHAM, N.H. — The moment you step out into the frozen air on the way up Mount Washington — one of the most frigid spots in the lower 48 — the icy wind steals your breath and freezes your eyelashes. You can’t blink. The cold stabs your face and numbs your earlobes to rubber.
articles.byline: By Jess Bidgood, Katharine Q. Seelye and Jack Healy

articles.headline: When It Costs Double to Let Your 12-Year-Old Fly Alone
articles.snippet: Southwest will let 12-year-olds fly solo. Other airlines want them (and 13- and 14-year-olds) in their unaccompanied minor programs for an extra $150 each way. But why?
articles.abstract: Southwest will let 12-year-olds fly solo. Other airlines want them (and 13- and 14-year-olds) in their unaccompanied minor programs for an extra $150 each way. But why?
articles.lead_paragraph: This is a tale of two flights and one 12-year-old who wanted to fly on her own between New York City and Chicago a few weeks after her birthday.
